citation.article-title: The first methane-oxidizing bacterium from the upper mixing layer of the deep ocean.: Methylomonas pelagica sp. nov.

p.s: Description of Methylomonas pelagica sp. nov.
Methylomonas pelagica (pelagica the first isolations were obtained from pelagic (open ocean) seawater in the Sargasso Sea)
The ultrastructure, metabolism, and DNA base composition of this species agree with the description of the genus Methylomonas as presently consituted [37].

Although the practice has been to avoid new species descriptions until a better characterization of extant isolates has been made, the distinctive properties and serology of this species do permit it to be described at this time.
Short rods, 0.5 μm in width by 0.8-1.2 μm in length.
Motile by a single, polar flagellum.
On purified agarose-seawater gels with appropriate nutrients and an atmosphere containing methane, small white, uniform, regular convex, soft colonies form which achieve a diameter of 1-2 mm.
Cytomembranes occur as stacked lamellae with fiat plates.
Utilizes only methane and methanol for growth, with formaldehyde being copiously leaked to the medium on the latter substrate.
These one-carbon units are assimilated via the ribulose monophosphate pathway for formaldehyde fixation.
Unable to grow on other C1 compounds or on C-C bonded organic matter.
Ammonia and nitrate, but not dinitrogen, serve as sources of nitrogen.
Able to grow at 20°C and 30°C but not at 10°C The mol % G+C content in the DNA is 49.

Possibly associated with particles of algal debris, produced by grazing and senescence in the upper ocean, that become anoxic and ferment to produce methanol and methane in an otherwise oxygen-saturated water column.
Type strain AA-23 (NCMB 2265) has been deposited in the National Collections of Industrial and Marine Bacteria Ltd. (Torrey Research Station, PO Box 31, Aberdeen, Scotland, UK AB9 8OG).
